In situ-formed cobalt embedded into N-doped carbon as highly efficient and selective catalysts for the hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes under mild conditions Yueling Cao 1 Kangkai Liu 1 Chen Wu Hepeng Zhang * Qiuyu Zhang * Key Laboratory of Special Functional and Smart Polymer Materials of Ministry of Industry and Information Technology. Graphical abstract Inhibiting the dehalogenation is the main challenge when halogenated nitrobenzenes are hydrogenated using H2 as hydrogen source by heterogeneous catalysis. Herein, the earth-abundant cobalt embedded into N-doped carbon (Co@CN) catalysts were fabricated via one-pot pyrolysis of tannic acid, Co(NO3)2·6H2O and melamine, which can function as a highly efficient non-noble-metal-based heterogeneous catalyst for selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes. Chloroanilines, bromoanilines, and iodoanilines, including all regioisomers, could be obtained with excellent selectivity (typically >99 %) at 60 °C under 1 MPa H2, at almost complete conversion of the substrates. Additionally, Co@CN demonstrated excellent catalytic stability and could be reused at least five times without obvious loss of catalytic activity and selectivity. Therefore, the Co@CN catalyst exhibits vast potential for future industrial application in the selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes. Keywords One-pot pyrolysis Halogenated nitrobenzenes Selective hydrogenation N-doped carbon supported Co 1 Introduction Halogenated anilines are series of crucial intermediates for the production of various high valued chemicals, such as organic dyes, pharmaceuticals, pesticides and photosensitive materials [1–3]. These widely applied halogenated anilines have been successfully synthesized from corresponding halogenated nitrobenzenes with stoichiometric reducing agents such as Fe, Zn, Sn, or hydride reagents [4–6]. Unfortunately, these processes are not environmentally sustainable because of the generation of stoichiometric amounts of harmful chemical wastes. Obviously, catalytic hydrogenation is the most environmentally friendly and cost-effective method for the preparation of halogenated anilines, using supported transition metals and gaseous hydrogen (H2) as the catalyst and reducing agent, respectively. However, the most difficult challenge in this catalytic hydrogenation process is to inhibit the cleavage of the weak carbon-halogen (C–X) bond, forming aniline (Scheme 1 ) [3,7]. In fact, the undesired dehalogenation reaction may become more prominent from C-Cl to C–I bond because of the following reasons. Firstly, the amino group in the halogenated anilines can function as an electron-donating group, which could promote the hydrogenolysis of the C-Cl bond in chloroanilines, making the undesired dehalogenation reaction occur [8–10]. Additionally, the much weaker C–I bond relative to the C-Cl bond results in the much easier hydrogenolysis because of the large atomic diameter as well as low electronegativity of iodine [10–12]. However, compared with chloroanilines, the iodoanilines and bromoanilines with weaker C–X bonds are more valuable intermediates in various organic synthesis reactions [13,14]. So far, however, the hydrogenation of p-halogenated nitrobenzene is mainly focused on the chloro substituents [3,15]. Based on the above discussion, developing an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for halogenated nitrobenzenes hydrogenation with a wide substrate scope is not only more challenging but also highly desirable. Recently, the most reported heterogeneous catalysts are mainly based on noble metal, such as Pt/TiO2, Pt/FeOx, Ir/TiO2-FeOx, and Ru/NPC [16–22]. However, there are several disadvantages impeding the large-scale application of this kind of catalysts. For example, the dehalogenation phenomenon cannot be completely avoided in the reaction. To improve the selectivity of these catalysts, modification by alloying or poisoning with other metal oxides or molecules are commonly used, but at the expense of catalytic activity [23–26]. Furthermore, the high cost and scarcity of noble metal resources make them uneconomic for practical application [27]. In view of the drawbacks of noble metal catalysts, series of non-noble metal catalysts were developed successively [9,28–34]. For example, Raney nickel catalyst has been reported that it can be successfully applied in the selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes, but inhibitors are needed to inhibit the dehalogenation phenomenon [9]. Fe-based catalysts have also been found to be selective for this reaction. But only 97 % selectivity for the 5-chloro-2-methoxyaniline was obtained, and relatively harsh reaction conditions (120 °C, 5 MPa H2) were needed [28]. Additionally, Beller et al. reported that the halogenated nitrobenzenes could be transformed into the corresponding anilines over cobalt-phenanthroline complexes derived Co oxide-N/C catalyst under 5 MPa H2 at 110 °C [29]. However, for the 3-chloroaniline and 4-chloroaniline, only 95 % selectivity was achieved. Wang et al. also demonstrated that the Co°/Co3O4@NCNTs catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of substituted nitroarenes with a wide scope under 3 MPa H2 at 110 °C [30]. Similar problem, slight dehalogenation happened and only 96 % selectivity was obtained for the 3-iodoaniline. It can be seen that these non-noble metal catalysts also suffer from some limitations such as the occurrence of slight dehalogenation, relatively costly nitrogen-containing precursors, high reaction temperature (> 100 °C) and/or H2 pressure (>2 MPa). Consequently, the development of a cost-effective non-noble metal catalyst system with both high selectivity and activity for halogenated nitrobenzenes hydrogenation is highly desirable. Tannic acid (TA), extracted from plant tissue, contains abundant galloyl or catechol groups, making it possess a strong binding affinity for various metal ions. More importantly, low price, the abundance, and environmental sustainability of TA grant it highly practical for many applications [35–37]. For example, the metal-TA coordination polymers have been widely used as a versatile platform for the functional surface engineering [38–40]. Moreover, TA also exhibits great potential as carbon precursors for the fabricating metal/carbon composites using its strong chelating ability to metal ions. Herein, we demonstrate the successful synthesis of N-doped carbon supported Co (Co@CN) catalysts through one-pot pyrolysis of a Co (Ⅱ)-TA coordination polymers with melamine. Co (Ⅱ)-TA coordination polymers play an important role in preventing the Co species from aggregation during pyrolysis process. Melamine, a common industrial chemical, can function as a soft template for the formation of sheet-like N-doped carbon and the dispersion of Co NPs (nanoparticles). The Co@CN catalyst displayed excellent catalytic performance for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes under 1 MPa H2 at 60 °C, which is better than that of the most previous reported Co-based catalysts (Table S4). For the chloroanilines, bromoanilines, and iodoanilines, including all regioisomers, 99 % selectivity could be achieved at almost complete conversion of the substrates. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Melamine (AR, 99 %), Tannic acid (AR, 99 %), 2-chloronitrobenzene (AR, 99 %), 3-chloronitrobenzene (AR, 98 %), 4-chloronitrobenzene (AR, 99 %), 3-bromonitrobenzene (AR, 99 %), 4-bromonitrobenzene (AR, 99 %) and 3-iodonitrobenzene (AR, 99 %) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. 2-bromonitrobenzene (AR, 99 %), 2-iodonitrobenzene (AR, 98 %) and 4-iodonitrobenzene (AR, 98 %) were purchased from McLean (Shanghai) Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (AR, 99 %), ethanol (AR, 99.8 %) and cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (AR, 99 %) were purchased from Guanghua (Guangdong) Technology Co., Ltd. Cobalt (II) acetylacetonate (AR, 98 %) was obtained from Civic (Shanghai) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. All the reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The preparation of Co@CN catalysts involved one-pot pyrolysis of a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, TA and melamine, similar with previous reports [41,42]. In a typical experiment, the aqueous solution containing 500 mg of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and a certain amount (300, 400, 500, 600 mg) of TA was stirred for 1 h, and then, 5 g of melamine was added into the above solution to form a slurry. After that, the slurry was heated at 80 °C until completely drying to form a powder. The dried powder was transformed into a furnace and underwent thermal treatment at 350 °C for 2 h and then at 550 °C for 2 h, finally at 700 °C for 2 h under nitrogen flow of 200 mL/min. The pyrolyzed samples were denoted as Co@CN-X, where X represents the amount of TA used in the catalyst preparation. For comparison, Co@C-TA, and Co@CN-Mel were obtained through the same procedure. Additionally, the mixture of TA (400 mg), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (500 mg) and melamine (5 g) was also pyrolyzed at 350 ℃ and 550 ℃, and the samples were named as Co@CN-400-350 and Co@CN-400-550, respectively. 2.3 Characterizations The crystallographic phase of the as-synthesized materials was characterized by X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD, Shimadzu XRD-600, Cu Kα source, λ =1.5406 Å). The specific surface areas and pore size distribution were evaluated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms on an 3H-2000PS2 nitrogen adsorption apparatus (Beishide Instrument, China) at 77 K. Specific surface area and pore structure were determined by the standard BET method based on the relative pressure between 0.04 and 0.32. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) was employed to analyze the Co content in the obtained Co@CN samples on a USA Perkin Elmer NexION 350D. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization were carried out with an Axis Ultra DLD X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy(Al Kα radiation) produced by Kratos Company in the United Kingdom to analyze the surface chemical structure of the prepared catalysts. The morphology of catalysts was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Verios G4, FEI). The metal nanoparticles in the catalysts were observed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with a JEM-2100. The mean particle size and size distribution were calculated based on over 200 individual particles. The CO chemisorption test was carried out in the chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics Auto Chem 2920, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using a pulse of 10 % CO/90 % He at 40 °C. Supposing the CO and Co stoichiometry was 1:1, the adsorption capacity of carbon monoxide and surface area of cobalt metal were calculated by following equations.: (1) C O u p t a k e = n C O m C o (2) m e t a l a r e a = S C o × R × n C O m C o where nCO is the adsorption capacity of carbon monoxide(mol), mCo is the true content of cobalt in the prepared catalyst(g), R is Avogadro's constant (6.022 × 1023 mol−1), SCo is the cross-sectional area of Co (0.0662 nm2). 2.4 Catalyst tests Selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes was perform to evaluate the intrinsic performance of the catalyst. In a typical experience, 20 mg catalyst, 0.5 mmol substrate and 5 mL ethanol were added to the Teﬂon inner layer of the stainless-steel autoclave. After a full removal of the air in the autoclave, the autoclave was pressurized with 1 MPa H2 then heated from room temperature to 60 ℃ and kept at 60 ℃ for a desired reaction time with a magnetic stirring (1000 rpm). The solution of product was analyzed by a Fuli 9720 gas chromatography (GC) with SE-54 capillary column (30 m ×0.32 mm ×0.5 μm) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The basic parameters of GC were set as follow: the N2 with a flow rate of 30 mL/min was used as carrier gas and the temperature of sample inlet and detector was 250 ℃. The column box temperature program was as follow: first holding at 70 ℃ for 1 min, then increasing from 70 ℃ to 240 ℃ with a heating rate of 12 ℃/min, finally holding at 240 ℃ for 0.5 min. The stability and reusability of the Co@CN-400 catalyst was investigated in the hydrogenation of 3-bromonitrobenzene under the same conditions as mentioned above except using the recovered catalyst. Typically, after the first cycle test, the catalyst was collected with an external magnet and washed with ethanol. Then the recycled catalyst was tested under the same conditions: 3-bromonitrobenzene (0.5 mmol), ethanol (5 mL) at 60 ℃ and 1 MPa H2 for 1 h (the second cycle). Subsequent stability experiences were carried out on the same catalyst by the same reaction step. However, after four runs, the catalyst was collected and reduced under hydrogen reduction furnace with 10 % H2/90 % Ar at 250 ℃ for 2 h. After that, 10 mg of catalyst was taken from them and was tested under similar reaction conditions: reduced Co@CN-400 (10 mg), 3-bromonitrobenzene (0.25 mmol), ethanol (5 mL) at 60 ℃ and 1 MPa H2 for 1 h (the fifth cycle). Subsequent stability experiences were performed on the same catalyst by the same reaction step. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication and characterization of catalysts The synthetic strategy of Co@CN catalysts was illustrated in Scheme 2 . Briefly, the Co@CN catalysts were achieved by one-pot multistep pyrolysis of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, TA, and melamine. Firstly, condensation of the melamine in the presence of the Co and carbon precursors might result in the formation of Co-O-C on the melem skeleton at 350 ℃. A holding sequence at 550 ℃ led to the formation of sandwich-like structure, during which the melem and TA further condensed to form graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) and carbon skeleton in the interlayer of g-C3N4, respectively. Meanwhile, the generated Co NPs were confined within the sandwich layers. High-temperature (700 ℃) annealing led to the complete decomposition of g-C3N4 and the formation of N-doped carbon. Meanwhile, the Co NPs were encapsulated into the N-doped carbon sheets, and finally the catalysts formed. To uncover the formation mechanism of Co@CN catalysts, the mixture of TA, Co(NO3)2·6H2O and melamine was pyrolyzed at 350 ℃ and 550 ℃. As shown in Figure S1, for the Co@CN-400-350, a series of peaks centered at 12.4, 13.7, 19.4, 22.1, 25.5, 27.2 and 30.4° are observed and the main peak is located at 25.5°, which is consistent with the XRD patterns of melem in the literature [43,44]. For the Co@CN-400-550, two peaks at 27.5° and 13° appear, indicating the presence of g-C3N4 in the sample [45]. More importantly, for the both samples no peaks belonged to cobalt oxide or metallic cobalt was observed, implying that the cobalt might be well dispersed on the support. After that, the morphology of the above samples was investigated via SEM and TEM (Figure S2). The Co@CN-400-350 shows 2D nanosheet structure with uneven size, and a layered structure were observed with overlapping g-C3N4 in Co@CN-400-550. The TEM images of Co@CN-400-350 and Co@CN-400-550 also reveal the nanosheet structure, but the latter is thinner than the former. Additionally, no obvious metal NPs could be detected in both Co@CN-400-350 and Co@CN-400-550 samples, indicating that the cobalt oxide might be well dispersed and completely embedded into the g-C3N4 framework, which is in line with XRD results. To further verify this conclusion, mapping analysis of element distribution over Co@CN-400-550 was carried out by STEM-EDS (Figure S3). As expected, all of the Co, C, N, and O atoms were homogeneously distributed in the whole sample, confirming the well dispersion of cobalt. Based on above discussion, it can be found that all these observations are in line with the forming process of catalyst illustrated in Scheme 2. The porosity of the as-prepared Co@CN catalysts pyrolyzed at 700 ℃ with different TA usage was measured by N2 sorption (Fig. 1 ). All of them showed typical Ⅳ type isotherms, indicating the mesoporous structure of these samples [46]. More importantly, as shown in Table 1 , the usage of TA significantly affects the textural properties of these samples. Specifically, the BET surface area increases in the following order: Co@CN-600 (87.9 m2/g) < Co@CN-500 (99.9 m2/g) < Co@CN-300 (328.0 m2/g) < Co@CN-400 (343.0 m2/g). However, for the Co@C-TA and Co@CN-Mel samples, lower BET surface area (115.3 and 131.1 m2/g, respectively) could be observed (Table S1) due to the fact that the lack of enough carbon source for the formation of carbon support when TA or melamine was used as the only carbon source. This might be mainly ascribed to the fact that the presence of both TA and melamine can offer adequate carbon source, thus favoring to the formation of N-doped carbon (CN) with high BET surface area, which is consistent with previous report [30]. However, when the usage of TA is too much, the textural properties of CN is more similar with that of Co@C prepared by using TA only because the soft template role of melamine is greatly weaken (as shown in Table S1). Additionally, the pore volume of various Co@CN catalysts shows the similar trend. These results implied that there is an optimal value for obtaining the catalyst with the highest BET surface area and pore volume. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of various Co@CN catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . For the Co@CN samples with the usage of TA in the range from 300 to 500 mg, three peaks at 44.2, 51.5 and 75.8°, corresponding to the metallic Co, were observed. More importantly, the peak intensity of metallic Co decreased dramatically when the usage of TA was 500 mg, even more no obvious peak belong to metallic Co were observed when the usage of TA was up to 600 mg. To further investigate the effect of TA amount on the dispersion of Co NPs, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was performed. As shown in Fig. 3 , the mean particle size of Co NPs decreased with increasing the amount of TA in the following order: Co@CN-300 (15.5 nm) > Co@CN-400 (11.8 nm) > Co@CN-500 (8.5 nm) > Co@CN-600 (5.8 nm), which is in line with XRD results. It should be noted that for the Co@CN-600 catalyst, no obvious Co NPs could be observed in most of TEM images (as shown in Figure S4), implying that most of Co atoms may be atomically dispersed on the surface of N-doped carbon. To investigate the role of TA in the dispersion of Co NPs, the Co@C-TA and Co@CN-Mel samples prepared by using TA and melamine only, respectively, were also analyzed by TEM. As shown in Figure S6, both of them exhibited larger mean particle size (41.2 nm and 21.2 nm, respectively). This might be mainly ascribed to the fact that when TA or melamine was used as the carbon source only, the carbon support formed in situ exhibited low surface area (as shown in Table S1), which is detrimental to the dispersion of Co NPs. Based on above discussion, it can be, therefore, concluded that both TA and melamine are indispensable for the dispersion of Co NPs. Firstly, the presence of TA can coordinated with cobalt ions, which is beneficial to prevent the aggregation of Co NPs during pyrolysis process. Moreover, the presence of melamine can be served as the soft template for the formation of N-doped carbon with high surface area, thus further favoring the dispersion of Co NPs. Considering the fact that the catalysts prepared by one-pot pyrolysis method possess core-shell structure that metal NPs encapsulated by carbon layers, which may block the active sites, the calculation of the exposure degree of cobalt NPs in different catalysts from the irreversible adsorption of CO was investigated to further corroborate the relationship between the size of Co NPs and the amounts of active sites. As shown in Table 2 , the CO uptake and metal area significantly increased with the increase of TA usage from 300 to 400 mg, which may be ascribed to the fact that Co@CN-400 catalyst possessed smaller Co NPs than Co@CN-300 catalyst (Fig. 3). However, when the TA usage was up to 500 mg, the CO uptake and metal area decreased sharply to 0.36 μmol/gCo and 14.4 m2/gCo, respectively, which is contradicted with the generally accepted conception that the smaller metal NPs normally exhibit higher metal area. Further increasing the TA usage to 600 mg, both the metal area and CO uptake exhibited the same trend. This may result from the fact that most parts of the cobalt NPs would be completely embedded into resultant N-doped carbon network in the process of preparing catalyst by one pot pyrolysis, and thus loss their availability of surface sites [42,47]. Based on above description, it can be concluded that the TA amount used in the catalyst preparation is a key factor for the dispersion and exposure degree of Co NPs. XPS analysis was also conducted to explore the chemical composition and valence of various Co@CN catalysts. Co 2p spectra of Co@CN-X exhibited an obvious shift of binding energy when the TA amount increased from 300 to 600 mg. This may be ascribed to the change in electronic structure as a function of cluster size, which is consistent with previous reports [48,49]. In addition, Table 3 summarized the XPS-derived ratios of Co° and Cox+, giving evidence of the surface Co electronic state changes caused by the amount of TA used in catalyst preparation. The percentage of Co° increased from 45.9%–59.3% with an increase of TA amount from 300 to 400 mg, but decreased to 37.2 % when the TA amount was up to 500 mg. Additionally, further increasing the TA amount to 600 mg, obvious positive shift of Co 2p binding energy was observed, and no peak belonging to Co° could be detected. This might result from that more surface Co atoms have an interaction with the oxygen derived from TA, which is in line with TEM result (Figure S4) that no Co NPs were observed in most part of Co@CN-600 catalyst, implying the atomic dispersion of these Co atoms. 3.2 Screening of catalysts To gain insight into the relationship between catalyst structure and their performance, the selective hydrogenation of 3-bromonitrobenzene over various Co catalysts were performed. As shown in Table 4 , the TOF value increased with the rise of TA dosage, and reached the highest (4.8 h−1) at 400 mg (entries 1 and 2). However, further increasing in TA dosage to exceed 400 mg led to a dramatic decline in the TOF value (entries 3 and 4). Even more, no reaction was observed when the TA dosage was up to 600 mg (entry 4). It’s worth noting that based on TEM results, the catalyst with smaller particle size (Fig. 3) did not possess a higher TOF value, which is contradicted with the generally accepted concept that the metal NPs with high dispersion normally exhibit high catalytic activity. [46] This may be mainly resulted from the fact that partial Co NPs are completely encapsulated by outer carbon layers, leading to less contact between these Co NPs and 3-bromonitrobenzene, and thus the available Co NPs would be much less if the dosage of TA become higher, which is similar with previous report [42]. To verify this conclusion, two kinds of Co@CN catalysts with high TA dosage were heat treated in both air and hydrogen atmosphere to destroy the carbon layers surrounding Co NPs. As expected, compared with untreated Co@CN-500 catalyst, an increase in 3-bromonitrobenzene conversion by a factor 7 could be achieved for the thermal treated Co@CN-500 catalyst (entry 8). For the Co@CN-600 catalyst, only a slight increase of catalytic activity was obtained after thermal treatment (entry 9), which might be mainly ascribed to the following fact. The carbon layers surrounding Co NPs were too thick to destroy by this thermal treatment under current conditions, thus only few parts of Co NPs exposed. Based on the above discussion, it can be found that the amount of TA used in the catalyst preparation is a key factor in affecting the hydrogenation performance of various Co-based catalysts. To further investigate the synergistic effect of each component in catalyst preparation process, a range of different control experiments were carried out. The blank run (only CN) had no activity in this experiment after 1.5 h, proving that Co NPs in Co@CN catalyst were the active sites for this reaction. However, the Co@C-TA catalyst prepared by using TA as the only carbon source was almost inactive for the reaction (entry 6). This might be ascribed to the larger Co NPs and thicker carbon layers surrounding Co NPs blocked the active sites as shown in Figure S6 and Table S2. Fortunately, a TOF of 2.8 h−1 could be achieved for the Co@CN-Mel (Melamine was used as the only carbon source) catalyst, which may result from the more available Co sites as well as higher BET surface area and pore volume (Figure S5, Table S1 and S2) in comparison with Co@C-TA catalyst. These observations implied that Co(NO3)2·6H2O, TA, and melamine might be all indispensable in the preparation of the samples, as well as directly related to the catalytic performance. To be exact, the TA plays a crucial role in preventing Co species from aggregation. The melamine is mainly responsible for the formation of sheet-like N-doped carbon and the dispersion of Co NPs. This conclusion could be further confirmed by the BET and TEM results of Co@C-TA and Co@CN-Mel samples (Table S1 and Figure S6). Table S1 shows that the specific surface areaof Co@C-TA and Co@CN-Mel was 115.3 and 131.1 m2/g, respectively, which are far lower than that of Co@CN-400. The total pore volume also exhibited the same trend. In addition, the mean particle size of Co@C-TA and Co@CN-Mel was 41.2 and 21.2 nm (Figure S6), respectively, which are far larger than that of Co@CN-400. Wang et al. also reported that the sheet-like structure of N-doped carbon was ascribed to the g-C3N4 formed from the polymerization of melamine [30,50] (Fig. 4 ). With the aim to obtain clear insights of the evolution of halogenated anilines selectivity with reaction time, the selective hydrogenation of 3-bromonitrobenzene and 3-iodonitrobenzene over Co@CN-400 catalyst was performed. As shown in Fig. 5 , both the 3-bromonitrobenzene and 3-iodonitrobenzene could be transformed smoothly into corresponding halogenated anilines with initially a nearly zero order in concentration, and no intermediate was detected during the whole reaction. More importantly, both the 3-bromoaniline and 3-iodoaniline were produced preferentially, with a nearly 100 % selectivity within 120 min and 150 min, respectively. Moreover, only a very slight dehalogenation from 3-bromoaniline or 3-iodoaniline to produce aniline was observed even when the reaction time was prolonged to 180 min. Based on the above analysis and discussion, we can safely say that the Co@CN-400 can function as an excellent catalyst for the chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroaromatics with different halogen substituents. The mechanism of halogenated nitrobenzenes hydrogenation is always important, thus many efforts have been devoted to this filed [51–53]. However, it is still unsettled at present. The most prevailing viewpoint is that the catalytic performance of catalyst is depended on the adsorption behavior of halogenated nitrobenzenes on the active sites [51–53]. In this work, the mechanism for catalytic hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes over Co@CN catalyst was proposed as the following (Scheme 3 ). Initially, the hydrogen molecule is adsorbed on the surface of Co NPs, and then dissociated to form two adsorbed hydrogen (H·). After that, the adsorbed hydrogen reacts with the adsorbed nitro group to form the nitroso compound, and then the nitroso further reacts with the adsorbed hydrogen to produce the halogenated phenylhydroxylamine. Finally, the reduction of hydroxylamine with the adsorbed hydrogen carries out to generate the halogenated aniline, which desorbs into the solution to get the final product. Considering the fact that catalyst recyclability is a key factor to robust heterogeneous catalysts, the stability of the Co@CN-400 catalyst for the hydrogenation of 3-bromonitrobenzene was investigated (Fig. 6 ). Unfortunately, the conversion of 3-bromonitrobenzene decreased gradually with the reaction cycles, being halved for the fourth run, despite maintenance of perfect selectivity throughout, which may be attributed to the following reasons. Firstly, the loss of catalyst is inevitable during the re-usability testing process, which will influence the next reuse test of the ‘used’ catalyst. Moreover, it’s well known that the surface atoms of non-noble metal catalysts (e.g., Co and Fe) are easily oxidized when exposure to air, which will also lead to the decrease of their catalytic activity [54,55]. To confirm this conclusion, the following experiments were performed. The Co@CN-400 catalyst after four times reuse was recovered and washed with ethanol several times, then dried at 40 ℃ overnight in a vacuum oven. After that, the dried Co@CN-400 catalyst was reduced at 250 ℃ for 2 h in hydrogen atmosphere. Finally, 10 mg of catalyst was taken from them and tested under following reaction conditions: 3-bromonitrobenzene (0.25 mmol), ethanol (5 mL) and Co@CN-400 (10 mg), at 60 ℃ and 1 MPa hydrogen for 1 h. Gratefully, the activity can be recovered again (the fifth cycle), almost the same as the fresh catalyst. Moreover, in view of the TEM and ICP results of the Co@CN-400 catalyst before and after reaction (Table S3, Fig. 7 ), no obvious Co leaching and particle aggregation were observed. According to the above discussion, it could be confirmed that the loss of catalyst and oxidation of Co NPs during the re‐usability tests are the main reasons for the decline of catalytic activity. Considering the fact that both the loss of catalyst and oxidation of Co NPs can be avoided in real industrial applications, it is, therefore, concluded that the Co@CN-400 is an outstanding catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes. Finally, the general scope of the Co@CN-400 catalyst was investigated for the hydrogenation various halogenated nitrobenzenes (Table 5 ).The hydrogenation of 1-, 3-, and 4-chloronitrobenzene that were all fully converted to the corresponding chloroanilines with an excellent selectivity (>99 %, entries1, 2, and 3). Additionally, for a series of bromonitrobenzene (entries 4, 5, and 6) and iodonitrobenzene (entries 7, 8, and 9) regioisomers containing C-Br and C–I bonds that are more susceptible to hydrogenolysis, the Co@CN-400 catalyst also afforded excellent halogenated aniline yields (typically >99 %), successfully inhibiting the undesired dehalogenation for all regioisomers. Based on our existing knowledge, a selective heterogeneous catalytic system of non-noble metals is reported for the first time in our research, which can be used for chemo selectivity hydrogenation of various halogenated nitrobenzenes (especially for iodo-nitrobenzene) with all regioisomers. [15] 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a scalable, environmentally benign, and straightforward strategy for the synthesis of Co@CN was successfully developed. This Co-based catalyst displayed high catalytic activity, high selectivity, and a wide range of substrates in the selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitro benzenes under mild reaction conditions (60 ℃, 1 MPa H2). Additionally, the Co@CN catalyst was readily recycled due to its intrinsic magnetic properties and could be reused at least five times without an obvious decrease of catalytic performance. Series of catalyst characterizations indicated that the amount of TA used in catalyst preparation plays a crucial role in both the dispersion and the exposure degree of Co NPs. The lower dosage could lead to the aggregation of Co NPs, but the higher dosage would result in the Co NPs encapsulated by thick carbon layers, thus losing the surface accessibility of Co NPs. Finally, the one-pot pyrolysis of TA, metal salts, and melamine might afford an alternative choice for the preparation of metal@CN catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Inhibiting the dehalogenation is the main challenge when halogenated nitrobenzenes are hydrogenated using H2 as hydrogen source by heterogeneous catalysis. Herein, the earth-abundant cobalt embedded into N-doped carbon (Co@CN) catalysts were fabricated via one-pot pyrolysis of tannic acid, Co(NO3)2·6H2O and melamine, which can function as a highly efficient non-noble-metal-based heterogeneous catalyst for selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes. Chloroanilines, bromoanilines, and iodoanilines, including all regioisomers, could be obtained with excellent selectivity (typically >99 %) at 60 °C under 1 MPa H2, at almost complete conversion of the substrates. Additionally, Co@CN demonstrated excellent catalytic stability and could be reused at least five times without obvious loss of catalytic activity and selectivity. Therefore, the Co@CN catalyst exhibits vast potential for future industrial application in the selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes.
coredata.dc:title: In situ-formed cobalt embedded into N-doped carbon as highly efficient and selective catalysts for the hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes under mild conditions
